title: Why CSL's Paul Perreault loves email
text:
The US is home to CSL’s largest manufacturing operations and is the source of the strongest growth in revenue and earnings.

Perreault starts the day by checking emails using a triage approach similar to doctors in emergency wards.

“You can go to bed at midnight and clean up your emails but at 6am they're full again because somebody has been up working,” he says.

“So I colour-code it. If it comes from Brian [McNamee, chairman of CSL and former CEO] it's in red.

“If it only comes to me and I'm the only one on the e-mail on the “to” line it's a different colour – it's blue. If it's just to me I'll answer those more frequently.

“If I'm on the copy line it's all in grey. I give people feedback on email because I've had people say, ‘Well, you never answered my e-mail’ and I said: ‘Because you copied me, so why would I answer it?’

“I said if you're just doing it to cover yourself and make sure that you know people know that you copied me on it – why'?

“Then I get people that send these return/receipt requested emails. Well, it's like they want to know that I've read it. And I'm like, if you have time to check everybody's email and who read it, then you're not busy enough. So I will call them directly.

“When they get a call from me and I talk about their email, all of a sudden I don't get those emails any more.

“But I tell people if you want an answer from me put me on the “to” line and only me on the “to” line. And then if it's a silly question or something that you know really should be delegated to other people, we'll talk about that as well."

CSL CEO Paul Perreault and chairman Brian McNamee mark the 25th anniversary of its ASX listing. Peter Braig

Perreault encourages email communication because it fits with the CSL culture of wanting people to be involved across the organisation and around the world.

“I do agree that emails can cause a lot of issues because everybody can be involved or say something because they have access to it and that's not necessarily a good thing,” he says. “When used appropriately I think it's fine but there is a lot of wasted time with emails.”

'Everywhere and nowhere all at once'

Perreault says his day usually includes phone calls, conference calls, video calls and site visits. If he is in Utah he will work from home. He speaks to chairman McNamee every week.

“It's a global company so you have to be everywhere and nowhere all at once, right?” he says.

“It's a very difficult life for the family. It's difficult for people in the company that want access to me if I'm not in the right geography or time zone, but I'm constantly available.

“I mean I rarely shut down. But I do have five hours during the night where my phone is only for family emergencies, so I set it for family. If it rings in the middle of the night, I know it's family and I know it's important.”

Perreault says he has less control over what is in his diary at CSL than at any other time in his career, which included 15 years at Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories, now part of Pfizer, before joining CSL in 2004 through the acquisition of Aventis Behring.

“There are certain things that are in my diary two years out - board meetings, the AGM, results, roadshows and the things that you have to do as a CEO that you need to schedule,” he says.

He spends about 100 days of each year in Melbourne, which is the location of several CSL factories, the CSL research hub and is home to several members of the global leadership team, including the chief financial officer David Lamont and chief scientific officer Andrew Cuthbertson.

“I'm here not just for the board, shareholders and results but also because we have a big business here as well especially with our R &D hub, with Broadmeadows and with the flu manufacturing in the southern hemisphere in Parkville.

On the road 200 days a year

Perreault says he will need to spend an increasing amount of time in Australia because of the expansion of the R &D hub to involve more biotech start-ups and the construction of new bespoke headquarters in Melbourne's Elizabeth Street.

Advertisement

“I'm gonna need to be here to make sure that all of that is appropriately being done,” he says. “But the operational side of the business is really out of the US because it is the largest market by far and that's where a lot of the development work is done.

“Our largest manufacturing facilities are in the US and our plasma collection comes out of the US and that's almost half of our employee base working hard every day to collect plasma from these wonderful donors. So, it's all of those things that take my time.”

Perreault says when he became CEO of CSL in July 2013 he did not want to be like the CEOs he used to complain about who did not know enough about what was going on in the business.

“So, I get criticised by people, including board members, that I travel too much but I'm on the road you know over 200 days a year and it's travelling to the sites, it’s the roadshows, it's the Australia piece, it's the US piece,” he says.

“It's the connection with people, it's the management by walking around, it's showing people that you're interested in what they're doing in the organisation. And if it's not that, I'll do video conferencing.”

Perreault this year took the view that too much of his available time for working on CEO tasks was being taken up in the operations side of the business as he tried to connect everybody across a complex ecosystem.

CSL is different to most big pharma or biotech companies because 65 per cent of its costs are in raw materials and manufacturing, compared with about 65 per cent spent on R &D and marketing for others.

Advertisement

“I was feeling like I was the only one that could see across the organisation in terms of the impact of the various pieces and functions that contributed to everything starting with plasma supply, demand planning, IT and AI,” he says.

This resulted in the appointment in May of Paul McKenzie as chief operating officer with responsibility for ensuring the maximum efficiency in the CSL end-to-end supply chain.

Perreault says McKenzie has brought new thinking to CSL about a whole range of supply chain issues including its approach to packaging. Perreault wants to leverage CSL’s size to get better deals without compromising the company’s cast-iron commitment to patient safety.

In between site visits, conference calls, board meetings and investor engagement, Perreault is working on CSL’s 2030 strategy. He has to look forward that far because the typical life-cycle development of a new blood product is between eight and 12 years.

“If I’m not looking now what’s going to be there in 2030 I’ll be behind the eight ball every single time,” he says. “Innovation has to start early and it has to be sustainable.”
description: Perreault’s day starts with a 5am workout “to get the blood flowing” and then emails, which are colour-coded, and, don't bother cc-ing him if you want a reply.
